webTitle: Tesco boss Philip Clarke to go 'back to the floor' amid customer exodus

fields.standfirst: Move represents attempt to reinvigorate supermarket chain, whose market share has dropped below 30%
fields.body:
Tesco's boss, Philip Clarke, dramatically announced that he was going "back to the floor" today as the growing customer exodus from its UK supermarkets puts his job on the line.

Clarke is going back into the aisles, where he started his career, in a bid to reinvigorate the supermarket, which rakes in more than £1 in every £8 spent on the UK high street. His decision to return to the retail frontline claimed the scalp of the grocer's UK boss, Richard Brasher, who unexpectedly quit after more than 25 years.

"You can't have two captains in a team," said Clarke, who first clocked in at Tesco when he was a 14-year-old stacking shelves in the store managed by his father.

Clarke insisted there had been no bust-up, but sources close to Brasher suggested there had been a row over how to get sales back on track. Brasher was the architect of Tesco's £500m price cuts campaign, called the Big Price Drop, but which has since been nicknamed the Big Price Flop for its failure to win back hard-up shoppers who have defected to rivals Asda, Sainsbury's and Morrisons since its launch last year. It is said Brasher wanted to cut prices faster and deeper to win back shoppers, but Clarke resisted.

The grocer's problems were highlighted by recent industry figures that showed that this year Tesco's market share has dropped below 30%, its lowest level for almost seven years. The vast chain had its worst Christmas for 20 years and recently had to warn the City to expect lower profits for the first time in decades because the domestic chain desperately needed investment after being wrung dry to fund overseas expansion.

On Thursday, the Tesco boss insisted: "I've nothing but the highest admiration for him [Brasher]. This is a consequence of my wish to take a more active role in the day-to-day management, and nothing else."

Clarke has spent his entire working life at Tesco, and his willingness to roll up his sleeves comes at a time when experts say the company has "lost touch" not only with its shoppers but its basic housekeeping, with long queues at the checkout and customers carrying groceries home in plastic cones designed for fresh flowers because carrier bags have run out. "Tesco probably cut too much from store budgets, and service has declined," said Bryan Roberts, a Kantar Retail analyst.

When Clarke succeeded Tesco's long-serving boss Sir Terry Leahy last year, the safe internal appointment was applauded by investors who anticipated another decade of untrammelled financial success.

But the chain's growing domestic problems have tarnished Leahy's gilded legacy and have also led to a boardroom shake-up with the two other most senior executives, Andrew Higginson and David Potts, who – like Brasher – missed out on the top job, heading for the exit.

Tesco declined to comment on Brasher's financial settlement other than saying it would "reflect 25 years service". Tesco executives are among the UK's best paid, and last year the 50-year-old received a £2.2m salary and bonus package. Brasher is also sitting on free shares worth more than £5.5m handed to him by the company over the years and a pension pot of the same size.

Analysts said Brasher had a "glowing" career at Tesco and was a loss to the business. "Richard is something Tesco hasn't got a lot of – he's very cerebral," said Philip Dorgan, a retail analyst at Panmure Gordon. He had been in a difficult position with his boss "breathing down his neck", he said, but Clarke needed to call the shots "because he's next in line".

Retail experts say Tesco's neglected stores now require "eye-watering investment", with some estimating that Clarke will have to shell out £800m over the next two years to get stores and service up to scratch.

But while Tesco gets its house in order, the sands are shifting under it as food and clothing sales move to the internet and rivals open record numbers of new stores. In January, Clarke backed away from calling its more than 200 out-of-town hypermarkets "a white elephant" but said they were a "less potent force" and he did not need many more.

Tesco's reputation was tarnished by its involvement in last month's row over "slave labour" government work experience schemes that saw the unemployed, under the threat of losing their benefits, work for free in its stores. It patched things up by offering paid placements and trumpeting plans to hire 20,000 new staff, and said the two-year hiring spree would help it to hit "new levels of excellence in customer service".

"Tesco is not broken," said Roberts. "It just needs to pull its socks up."

webTitle: Lloyds denies former bosses £2.2m in bonuses

fields.standfirst: Ex-chief executive and three of his former colleagues denied payouts weeks after having part of 2010 bonuses clawed back
fields.body:
The former Lloyds Banking Group chief executive Eric Daniels and three of his former colleagues have been stripped of £2.2m of bonuses they were due to receive for cutting costs, including 28,000 jobs, following the rescue takeover of HBOS.

They have been denied the bonuses weeks after having part of their 2010 bonuses clawed back as a result of the £3.2bn of losses caused by the mis-selling of payment protection insurance.

Other senior bankers below board level have been handed payouts as a result of successfully integrating the troubled HBOS, even though the enlarged group is lossmaking and leaving the taxpayer with £10bn of losses on its 40% stake at Thursday night's 36p share price.

A stock exchange announcement by the bailed-out bank shows that bonuses awarded three years ago and linked to the integration of HBOS had paid out – which should have handed Daniels and the former head of retail Helen Weir, the former insurance boss Archie Kane, and Truett Tate, the ex-corporate banking head, some £2.2m.

The annual report also appears to indicate that the bonuses would have paid out, but it is understood that the board has decided in the last two weeks – since the annual report was prepared – that the awards should not be released to the former directors. An announcement may be made on Friday to clarify the situation. Daniels stood to receive £800,000 of shares and the other three around £500,000.

The annual report, published on Thursday , showed that António Horta-Osório, the chief executive who took two months off ill last year following a bout of sleeplessness, took home £1.9m in 2011 when his £1m salary was enhanced by bonuses and pensions. He was also awarded £4.2m of shares in 2011 when he was lured from Santander, and will be awarded £2.75m under a long-term incentive plan for 2012 that will pay out in three years, depending on performance.

The Portuguese banker received these sums after waiving his £2.4m annual bonus for 2011 because of the "tough financial circumstances of people", the bank's poor performance and his two months of absence.

The bank paid Daniels £855,000 last year even though he stopped being a director at the end of February 2011. He has a retirement pot of £5m, which pays out £223,000 a year.

Kane and Weir, who left in May, were handed £721,000 and £791,000 respectively, and Tate – who left three weeks ago – some £1.2m. The finance director Tim Tookey, who left last month, received £939,000.

Some of the departing executives could also continue to receive payouts for some time through long-term incentive plans. Tate, for instance, was awarded 3.1m shares during last year – worth £2m at the time – and has 5.2m in long-term incentive plans that could pay out in the future, worth around £1.8m at current share prices.

Weir is also able to hold on to 5m of shares she has been awarded in the past, which are yet to pay out and remain subject to performance criteria. Daniels will have his 3.4m of shares awards for 2009 and 5.1m of awards for 2010 under three-year performance schemes pro-rated to reflect that he left the bank before the performance periods had been completed.

Other senior bankers below board level were handed £725,000 of integration payouts. Mark Fisher, the former Royal Bank of Scotland banker hired by Lloyds to integrate the HBOS takeover, received 748,000 shares – £260,000 from the integration and a further 1.9m under a performance-related plan, selling most of the £950,000 of shares.

The three-year integration of HBOS, which has racked up £3.2bn of costs but saved £2bn a year, has proved controversial and the chairman, Sir Win Bischoff, has admitted that "with the benefit of hindsight now, obviously it [the merger] has not been as good an idea as people thought at the time". Last week, the Financial Services Authority condemned one of the units it bought with the HBOS deal – Bank of Scotland corporate – for "very serious misconduct" and would have fined the division as much as £100m if it had not been bailed out by the taxpayer.

The integration bonus was based on the cost savings being achieved as well as some non-financial measures. The bank disclosed last week that it had paid its eight highest-paid executives, below board level, a combined £16m.

webTitle: Why Greg Smith was right about Goldman Sachs | Larry Elliott

fields.standfirst: Resignation letters may be self-serving, but Smith's rang true: Wall Street is a conspiracy of the super-rich against the public
fields.body:
It's easy to dismiss Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs banker, as a man with a grudge. This could be a classic case of sour grapes, with Smith's claim that his former employers were "morally bankrupt" and described customers as "muppets" the result of him being overlooked in the dog-eat-dog world of investment banking.

In the circumstances, though, it doesn't really matter whether Smith was a principled whistleblower or someone not really up to the job getting his own back. Why? Because his accusations had the ring of truth about them: what he said chimes not just with what Goldman's customers think of the Wall Street behemoth, but with the deep public suspicion that big finance is lining its own pockets at the expense of Main Street.

That is an entirely justified suspicion and is a function of two developments – one long-term and one more recent. The big structural change on Wall Street and in the City of London has been for the investment banks to become bigger and more integrated. That means that one team goes round trying to persuade companies to float shares, a second team of analysts then pens supposedly independent analysis suggesting the shares are a great buy, while a third team of traders makes money every time the shares move up and down on the stock market. There is a massive conflict of interest here.

There were obvious dangers in this process that stemmed from the gradual dismantling in the final quarter of the 20th century of the curbs placed on Wall Street after the Great Depression in the 1930s. They were, however, masked until the second big development: the final crisis of 2007-08. This not only exposed – brutally and repeatedly – the follies of investment banks that had allowed their greed to get the better of their judgement, but also turned the big beasts of Wall Street into supplicants for taxpayer handouts.

Those financiers who had spent the previous 15 years demanding that Washington get off the back of business suddenly found that there was case for government, after all – even if that only amounted to a willingness to write big cheques that would guarantee their annual bonuses. Rightly, ordinary voters were disgusted: privatising gain and socialising losses is not the way American capitalism (or any other form of it) is supposed to work.

To rub salt in the wound, once the immediate crisis was over, Wall Street insisted that the burden of clearing up the financial mess that Wall Street created be shouldered by ordinary voters – through cuts in public spending.

Where does this leave us? There are three conclusions from all this. The first is that Goldman Sachs has suffered reputational damage from the Smith attack. The public was tolerant of the excesses of the investment banking fraternity when times were good: when house prices are falling and real incomes are being squeezed, it tends to be less forgiving. There is no great love lost between Goldmans and its corporate customers, either.

The second conclusion is that it is time there was more competition in the investment banking industry. Returns on capital are high, and the reason for that is that the barriers are high for potential new entrants. It takes a lot of capital to set up an investment bank, which is why the industry operates as a self-serving oligopoly, rather than as a channel for productive investment in the real economy.

The final conclusion, therefore, is that if the competition does not happen naturally through market forces (and there is no hint that it will), then a much tougher regulatory regime is needed – so that the corporate finance and trading arms of investment banks are split into different firms.

That would limit the opportunity for conflict of interest and would cut the cost of finance to business. Above all, it would tackle what has become a colossal conspiracy by the super-rich against the general public.

webTitle: Stephen Hester: government needs to start selling stakes in RBS and Lloyds

fields.standfirst: RBS chief executive's theory is that the share prices of Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland might even start to improve once the government sales start
fields.body:
Looking at the share prices of Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland is not a pretty sight for the taxpayer. At Thursday's closing prices, the paper loss on the 40% stake in Lloyds is £10bn (at 35p) and £21bn (at 26p) on the 83% stake in RBS.

Little wonder then that officials at UK Financial Investments (UKFI), which looks after the stakes in the bailed-out banks, told MPs this week that the shares might need to be sold at a loss. Today it was the turn of Stephen Hester, chief executive of RBS, to continue a tune he has been humming for some time: "The faster the government starts selling its stake, the better for everyone".

His theory is that the share price might even start to improve once the sales start. He told Andrew Marr a few weeks back that: "I do think that the first sale by the government will increase the value of the rest of the holding because investors, when they see that the government is actually selling, when they see that RBS is again a private sector company being run in a way that investors would want it to be run, I think that will give them confidence and help the whole thing, and help RBS."

Hester added: "It's natural that the first price at which you sell will be lower than the last price. Over time, each time you sell, hopefully you'll sell at higher prices, and what obviously matters is the average across a whole exercise rather than where you start".

UKFI's annual report shows that while the average price at which stakes in RBS were bought is 50.2p, the lowest price at which the shares were bought was 31.75p (April 2009) and the highest of the three tranches was 65.5p (the first bailout in December 2008).

For Lloyds, the average price was 72.2p but this can be reduced to 63.1p if the £2.5bn fee paid by the bank to exit the asset protection scheme in 2009 is included. Shares were also bought in three separate tranches - at a high of 182.5p and a low of 37p.

So, if averages are ignored, a sell-off in the shares in either or both banks could be presented in a number of ways - if, and it is a big if, investors can be convinced to buy them.

webTitle: Obama and Cameron mull releasing oil reserves, as Falklands oil row hots up

fields.standfirst: Price of crude falls by $3 a barrel on speculation of joint move, while Argentina threatens UK with legal action over drilling plan
fields.body:
The politics of oil took centre stage on Thursday as Britain quarrelled with Argentina over exploration off the Falkland Islands and opened talks with the US on joint action to try to subdue crude prices.

UK officials confirmed that David Cameron and Barack Obama had discussed such a presidential plan to release oil stocks at an Oval Office meeting. Speculation that the US and UK were preparing to co-operate in this way helped send Brent crude down by around $1 a barrel to $124, still very high by historic standards, although short of the record $148 in mid-2008.

Both leaders are under political pressure from motorists and consumers over soaring fuel costs.

Speaking in New York on Thursday, Cameron said: "We are all facing the problem of higher oil prices and that translates into the cost of filling up the family car, which is very high here in the US but frankly even higher in the UK.

"I want to try to help British families, just as Barack Obama wants to help American families. We didn't reach a decision yesterday about oil reserves but we discussed the issue and I think it is important that we do what we can to try to help families who are trying to make their family budgets add up."

Obama is particularly worried that high prices could derail his country's fragile economic recovery in a presidential election year.

Both of them are also aware that the Middle East – still the world's main oil producing area – remains highly volatile, a situation which could worsen if Israel attacks Iran, as some fear.

One British source said of a potential reserves plan: "President Obama is getting a lot of grief over the high price of oil."

Britain also responded on Thursday to a threat of legal action by Argentina against companies involved in energy exploration around the Falklands.

Argentina says Britain is flouting UN resolutions that call for talks and prohibit any unilateral action as long as the sovereignty dispute persists. Foreign minister Hector Timerman said offshore oil exploration amounts to a unilateral move.

At a news conference in Buenos Aires, the minister called the exploration and drilling activities illegal. He said Argentina would bring civil and criminal charges against the companies involved.

"With these actions we assume the responsibility of defending Argentina's natural resources," he said. "The South Atlantic's oil and gas are property of the Argentine people."

A UK Foreign Office spokesman said: "Hydrocarbon exploration is a legitimate commercial venture and the British government supports the rights of the Falkland islanders to develop their hydrocarbons sector."

"This right is an integral part of the right of self-determination, which is expressly contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights," he added, referring to a United Nations' treaty.

He said there could be no negotiations on the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands unless the 3,000 islanders wanted them.

Several companies have drilled in waters off the islands. British explorer Rockhopper has been seeking a partner to invest in the $2bn (£1.3bn) Sea Lion project. Borders & Southern and Falkland Oil & Gas are set to drill wells south of the islands this year.

An industry source in London said legal action against companies involved in Falklands oil exploration "will have no impact on Rockhopper's operations as they look to develop the Sea Lion project".

Borders & Southern declined to comment.

webTitle: Air Partner sees profits nosedive

fields.standfirst: Company which charters commercial and private jets for the British army and Philip Green, saw profits fall by nearly 20%
fields.body:
Air Partner, which charters commercial and private jets for clients that include the British army and Philip Green, the retail tycoon, saw profits nosedive in the first half with chairman Richard Everitt warning of more turbulence ahead.

Everitt, who took over from Aubrey Adams five weeks ago, described the market as "tough" with trading patterns "inconsistent" and visibility of forward bookings "difficult."

Some of the drivers of growth at Air Partner are falling away as the British and American military wind down operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, while corporate customers sit on their hands amid continuing economic uncertainty in the eurozone. The company charters commercial aircraft from operators such as Monarch and Easyjet.

It all looked so good for Air Partner until relatively recently: profit nearly doubled in 2010/11, with the advance also powered by rescue missions the company organised in the wake of the Arab Spring and the tsunami in Japan.

But results for the six months to 31 January, published on Thursday showed a different picture, reflecting the earnings warning issued in the new year. Profit fell by nearly 20% to £2.3m and revenue was down 8% to £120.5m. Shares plummeted nearly 5% to 271p and have lost more than 40% of their value in 12 months.

The company, which doesn't own any planes, but acts as a broker, said overcapacity in the commercial sector resulted in "lower trading levels against a strong comparable period this time last year."

Smaller private jets, chartered by the rich and famous, did better with revenue up 7% thanks in part to "client wins" from a growing number of wealthy individuals in the Ukraine and Russia. On the commercial side, a number of the contractual successes seen this time last year, and described by analysts as "one-offs," weren't repeated.

Broker Oriel Securities said: "We share management's caution about the remainder of the financial year. Overcapacity in the commercial market for wide-bodied jets has been the primary cause of Air Partner's profit decline."

Oriel added: "The market has been characterised by increased competition, depressed margins and, in certain circumstances, this has led some customers to cut out the middle man and source direct from the aircraft operators. In a broader context, the wind down of American and British military activity in Iraq and Afghanistan is in our view causing a period of readjustment in the charter market, which will last for some years."

But the broker said some developments bode well for future growth. These include an 8% increase in non-government revenue which accounted for 69% of first half sales, reducing Air Partner's reliance on Anglo-American military activities.

Everitt said: "The Board recognises the challenge in driving the business forward while market conditions are tough, but expects the actions already being taken, to increase sales and to address costs, will materially improve the underlying profitability of the business in the future."

He added: "The contribution made by Air Partner's operations outside the UK has also been important in this period. Revenues from international offices grew by 21%, making up 50% of the Group total.

"An upward trend is expected both in sales and in profit generation from outside the UK over the coming years."

webTitle: World Trade Organisation could be looking for Lamy's successor

fields.bodyText: By the end of next week, it will be clear who Barack Obama wants to run the World Bank. The job has gone to an American every time it has been up for grabs since the second world war, and in a presidential election year that is not going to change. There is, though, the possibility that there will be another vacancy at the head of a multilateral organisation if Francois Hollande defeats Nicolas Sarkozy and becomes the next French president. In those circumstances, there is speculation that Hollande would find a place in his administration for Pascal Lamy, the current director-general of the World Trade Organisation, perhaps as finance minister. Lamy's term at the WTO ends next year, he is flogging a dead horse in trying to conclude the Doha round of trade talks (already into their 11th year), and like Hollande he counts Jacques Delors as one of his mentors. Of course, this will be entirely theoretical if Sarkozy wins a second term. But if Lamy goes there is talk that Peter Mandelson, a former EU trade commissioner, might get the job. That would mean another top international job going to a developed country, but if developing countries want to avoid this they need to start thinking - now - about putting forward a credible candidate who can bring Doha to a successful conclusion.

webTitle: Network Rail fined £1m over level crossing deaths

fields.standfirst: Judge says 'corporate blindness and complacency' led to the deaths of two teenage girls at a level crossing in Essex in 2005
fields.body:
Network Rail has been fined £1m for safety failings that led to the death of two teenage girls at a level crossing six years ago, after the judge said the track operator's "corporate blindness" and "complacency" had led to criminal failure.

Olivia Bazlinton, 14, and Charlotte Thompson, 13, were killed by a train as they crossed the tracks by Elsenham station, Essex, December 2005.

Network Rail pleaded guilty earlier this year to three breaches of health and safety laws in a prosecution brought by the Office for Rail Regulation (ORR). At the hearing in January, it admitted failing to carry out a sufficient risk assessment, failing to properly control protective measures at the level crossing, and failing to prevent the girls from being exposed to the risks that led to their deaths.

The ORR reopened its investigation last year after the girls' families and the TSSA union demanded a public inquiry amid claims that crucial safety documents were not disclosed at the coroner's inquest in 2007. A railway inspector wrote in 2001 that the "risk of disaster" was "real" at a crossing where the public regularly found the temptation to ignore the lights irresistible.

Olivia and Charlotte were killed crossing the tracks on a footpath leading to the station platform. Warning lights and alarms were still sounding after a first Cambridge-bound train arrived in the station, but another train was about to pass. After the girls opened the unlocked gates and walked on to the crossing in an attempt to catch the Cambridge train, they were struck by the second train.

Judge David Turner QC, sentencing at Chelmsford crown court, ordered Network Rail to pay £60,000 costs on top of the £1m fine. He said it had demonstrated "narrow thinking, culpable corporate blindness and a complacency going beyond merely inefficient incompetency to entering the realm of criminal failure".

Chris Bazlinton, the father of Olivia, said he would still be seeking answers from Network Rail. He said of the sentence: "It's symbolic. The fine is a lot of money, although it comes out of the taxpayers' pocket because of the huge subsidy to Network Rail.

"The legal bit is over. We've got through that. But Network Rail said there was confusion about who knew about these documents. That's not good enough. I think there are senior people who knew more."

The families plan to meet the Network Rail chief executive, Sir David Higgins, again to pursue this, at his invitation. In a statement released afterwards, Higgins said: "On behalf of Network Rail I apologise for the mistakes made by us in this tragic case that contributed to the deaths of Olivia and Charlotte.

"Nothing we can say or do will lessen the pain felt by Olivia and Charlotte's families but I have promised the families that we will make level crossings safer, and we will deliver on that promise. Fundamental changes to the way we manage and look after the country's 6,500 level crossings have been, and are being, made."

Network Rail has closed more than 500 crossings in recent years. When bosses pledged to forgo any bonuses earlier this year, Higgins said any eventual award would go into a safety fund to improve crossings.

The ORR's director of railway safety, Ian Prosser, said: "Network Rail failed Olivia and Charlie and their families by not addressing the safety risks at the crossing, and the consequences were devastating. It is right that the company has apologised and pleaded guilty to breaches of health and safety law that led to their tragic and preventable deaths."

But, he added, the fact the ORR was bringing prosecutions showed "it is clear that Network Rail has significant work still to do".

webTitle: Property groups British Land and Land Securities tipped as predators, while FTSE falters again

fields.standfirst: Analysts at JP Morgan predict mergers in sector but investors remain cautious as eurozone saga drags on
fields.body:
Could there soon be a spate of acquisitions in the property sector?

That is the theory put forward in a note from JP Morgan Cazenove, which names Big Yellow, up 2.8p at 324.3p, Hammerson, 0.7p better at 420.8p, Helical Bar, 3p higher at 184p, and Workspace, steady at 242p, among the likely bid targets.

Predators could include British Land, 1.5p better at 502p, Land Securities, down 1.5p at 730p, and Simon Property, the US group which has just bought a near 29% stake in French real estate company Klepiere. The bank said:

As hoped for, European property stocks have bounced strongly by 13% since 9 January 2012, as a result of the European Central Bank's LTRO [cheap loan programme] and Simon Property's stake purchase in Klepierre. We believe companies should speed up with value creation, find a bride or risk being shipped out.
M&A [is set] to increase, as the sector is facing structural challenges and is trading at 29% discount to net asset value, while predators will exploit their relatively low cost of capital. We believe companies like Land Secs and in particular British Land should consider utilizing their low cost of capital for M&A purposes (following alstria's recent example), perhaps in combination with demerging specialized vehicles. We welcome recent strategy changes from companies like Hammerson and Wereldhave, but companies need to speed up, as others will exploit their cost of capital advantage. In this context, Simon Property's Klepierre deal should be a wake-up call.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished just 4.71 points lower at 5940.72, as the International Monetary Fund approved its €28bn loan to Greece and investors shrugged off overnight news that Fitch had threatened the UK's Triple A credit rating. A reasonable set of US economic numbers, including better than expected weekly jobless claims, helped sentiment.

Miners recovered some ground after recent worries about a slowdown in China, a key market for commodities. Kazakhmys climbed 18p to 961.5p, while Rio Tinto rose 67.5p to 3547.5p.

But Glencore dipped 1.15p to 412.2p. The company is said to be one of the potential bidders for Canadian grain specialist Viterra, whose shares were briefly suspended before it announced it had established a process for considering offers.

Essar Energy may be about to be kicked out of the FTSE 100 at the close of play on Friday following the latest quarterly reshuffle. But its shares added 1.2p to 113.6p after it completed another stage in the expansion of its Vadinar refinery in India. It has commissioned a diesel hydrotreater unit, leaving three more units to be brought on stream by the end of the month.

Elsewhere Next added 74p to £29.01 after better than expected figures from rival H&M and a buy note from Panmure Gordon ahead of next Thursday's full year figures. The broker said:

The company has already guided a 2012 pretax profit of "£7m either side of £565m". Our estimate is £572.6m, at the top of this guided range. The focus next Thursday will be on any new guidance for 2013. The January statement guided the market to 2013 profits "only slightly up" on 2012. Our estimate of £593.1m implies 3.6% growth, around 1% ahead of consensus on £586.6m. With stable year on year selling prices and a very favourable input pricing environment, we think that 2013 guidance is probably too conservative.

But Tesco fell 3.1p to 321.75p following news that Richard Brasher, the supermarket's UK head, had quit the board with immediate effect. In January the group issued a shock profit warning, and admitted it needed to improve customer service.

Whitbread dipped 8p to £179.10 after Investec began coverage with a sell recommendation. Analyst James Hollins said:

We believe the Whitbread bull case is running out of steam. The marginal rate of Costa expansion is tapering, we project a hotels revenue per available room decline in 2013 and its restaurants face material demand- and cost-led pressures, in our view. The shares are at a premium to our 1,450p price target, and with limited catalysts to drive the shares higher on a 12-month view, we initiate with a sell.

Shares in Shire slid 70p to £21.58 after the pharmaceutical group withdrew a US licence application for its treatment for Fabry disease, a rare genetic disorder, after signs regulators wanted more tests on the drug.

Shire had been supplying the drug Replagal in the US for around two years - it has been on the market in Europe since 2001 - following manufacturing problems with rival treatment Fabrzyme, made by Genzyme.

The company also announced the purchase of US biotech firm FerroKin BioSciences for up to $325m.

GlaxoSmithKline edged up 1p to £14.31 as the company agreed the sale of a number of its European over-the-counter brands including Zantac and hayfever spray Beconase to Belgium's Omega Pharma. The net cash proceeds of £310m will be returned to shareholders. Separately Glaxo was said to be one of a number of companies preparing second round bids for Turkey's MN Pharmaceuticals, which could be worth around $800m.

Among the mid-caps, Domino Printing Sciences dropped 103p to 560.5p or more than 15% after it said it was unlikely to see any sales growth this year because of difficult markets in Europe and fewer large orders from China. Seymour Pierce cut its recommendation from buy to hold but said:

We see no reason to panic though. Noting that we saw a similar wobble in forecasts in 2009 only for the end result to be little different to initial expectations we take our share price target back to 600p, equivalent to a 2012 PE of 17 times.

White van specialist Northgate fell 17.7p to 220.5p after warning 2012 profits would be at the lower end of expectations, due to weak rental demand in the UK and Spain, and the company was also taking a cautious view of 2013.

IT group Misys fell 2.5p to 322.5p after Swiss rival Temenos - which withdrew its merger proposal earlier this week - issued a downbeat trading update. Misys is still in the sights of two potential bidders, Vista Equity Partners and a joint bid from CVC Capital and ValueAct. Analysts at Espirito Santo said:

Temenos re-iterated its view that market conditions remain difficult and sales cycles are much longer compared to 2008-09. This is in line with our view that the market conditions in the banking software market are worse than what we saw in 2008-09. This clearly has negative implications for the potential price that [private equity companies] would be willing to pay [for Misys].

Finally Game Group jumped another 65% to 3.45p after the troubled retailer appeared to be handed a lifeline. Turnaround group OpCapita was understood to be in talks with Game's lenders, including the Royal Bank of Scotland, with a view to buying its debt as well as settling its bills with suppliers in full.

webTitle: Tesco's Clarke now in the firing line after Brasher's exit

fields.bodyText: It was little more than a year ago that Philip Clarke, freshly appointed as Tesco's chief executive, unveiled his new, expanded executive committee. "Given that the size and scope of the business has grown enormously, it is now the right time to enlarge it," explained Clarke. Of the 13 colleagues on that original committee, four have left Tesco or are about to do so — Andrew Higginson, David Potts, Laura Wade-Gery and now Richard Brasher, head of the UK operation, source of two-thirds of the profits. Change tends to come quickly in all big companies when a long-serving boss leaves and three of the departees (Higginson, Potts and Brasher) were disappointed candidates to succeed Sir Terry Leahy. Wade-Gery's exit was a straightforward poaching by Marks & Spencer; that happens too. But Brasher's resignation is different. Clarke explanation — "you can't have two captains in a team" — is odd. Clarke himself had set up the management structure and defined the roles. What's Clarke implying? That Brasher wanted to play different tactics? That's the rumour — that there was a dispute over pricing strategy in the UK, with Brasher wanting to push harder and Clarke unwilling to take the hit to profits. Or does Clarke simply mean that the big boss should get stuck in himself in central midfield when the team has conceded a sloppy own-goal and the fans are getting restless? For now, investors will probably accept the line that Clarke is displaying lead-from-the-front qualities. But it's not a risk-free move for him. When he expanded the executive committee a year ago, he was saying the chief executive of Tesco can no longer be everywhere at once. That judgment seemed correct at the time since the group now operates in 14 countries and employs almost 500,000 staff. If new fires break out in other parts of the empire, Clarke is open to the criticism that he's a micro-manager in a business that is now too big to be micro-managed. As retail analyst Nick Bubb put it: "It is hard to see how this will end happily. Will Phil Clarke take over running Tesco Bank when that goes off plan?" Whatever else Brasher was, he was a handy scapegoat if the UK sales fail to re-ignite. Clarke is now directly in the line of fire: he probably has only a year to demonstrate his way is best.

webTitle: Argos owner sees sales slump persisting

fields.standfirst: Chief executive Terry Duddy said trading conditions at Argos continued to be tough, with sales of TVs, video games and stereos down by more than 20%
fields.body:
Home Retail – the owner of Argos and Homebase – forecast another year of falling sales, as chief executive Terry Duddy urged the government to help low and middle-income consumers in next week's budget.

Argos like-for-like sales slumped 8.5% in the fourth quarter while sales at Homebase fell 6.5%. The company said it was on course to meet expectations for full-year underlying profits of around £100m, down sharply from £254m the year before, signalling a fifth consecutive year of falling profits.

Even online sales dropped 3% over the year, despite 16% growth in the UK's total online retail market in 2011.

Duddy said trading conditions at Argos continued to be tough, with sales of TVs, video games and stereos down by more than 20%. "Consumers will spend when there are exciting new products like iPad and Kindle," he said. "But TV, audio and video games markets haven't got that level of excitement."

At Homebase, he blamed the steep sales decline on consumers putting off big projects, such as kitchen and bathroom refurbishments.

Analysts say Argos's problems are self-inflicted and that it should consider store closures, as a growing proportion of sales shift to the internet.

Duddy said Argos's new managing director John Walden, who joined last month, had been given a free rein to examine all options for the struggling business, including closing some of its 748 shops. He said all of Argos's stores make money, but added that 185 leases come up for renewal over the next five years.

Philip Dorgan of Panmure Gordon said: "We note that the new managing director of Argos said that he had been given a blank piece of paper. We think that he needs to start writing a list of store closures on it. While it may be true that Argos has few stores that don't make a contribution to overhead, this does not mean that this will perpetuate in an online world, with both Tesco and Amazon continuing to invest substantially."

Walden said he is looking at what is the appropriate number of stores, as well as asking: "What is their role in the future? Do they serve a purpose other than pick-up?"

Home Retail has blamed the squeeze on living standards faced by low-income families for falling sales. Duddy argues that Argos customers, drawn from the mass market C2 and D socio-economic groups, are struggling because they have not benefited from falls in mortgage rates as much as those with higher incomes.

Today he welcomed proposals to raise the threshold at which people begin paying tax. "We think that's an important factor and would lead to an easing for the circumstances that people have got where they've just seen disposable income falling."

webTitle: Fitch UK downgrade threat a budget gift for George Osborne

fields.standfirst: Chancellor will say that the one certain way to see Britain's credit rating downgraded would be to let up on the government's deficit reduction plan
fields.body:
In one sense, the warning from Fitch that it might strip the UK of its AAA rating is good news for George Osborne. The chancellor was never realistically going to announce a giveaway budget next week, even though the public finances are looking a bit less poor than he expected at the time of the 2011 autumn statement. But now he has the perfect cover for keeping things tight. Osborne will say that the one certain way to see Britain downgraded would be to let up on the government's deficit reduction plan.

The fact is, of course, that there has already been some slippage on the original strategy, which was announced shortly after the 2010 election. That envisaged public spending cuts and tax increases being a thing of the past by the time of the 2015 election: that timetable now extends to halfway through the next parliament because weaker growth and higher unemployment has meant additional borrowing. In terms of its timing, there is now not a lot of difference between the coalition's plan and that sketched out by Alistair Darling before the last election.

For those on the political right, the lesson to be learned from the Fitch threat of a credit rating downgrade is clear: spending should be cut more aggressively in order to get the deficit reduction plan back on track. That, it is said, would reassure the rating agencies that the government meant what it said about putting the public finances back in order, as well as creating a lower-tax environment in which the private sector could flourish.

Those on the political left call this Herbert Hoover economics. Attempting to cut spending and reduce the deficit when growth is already weak will, it is said, merely lead to even higher unemployment and additional pressure on the public finances. Ed Balls is arguing that a short-term fiscal boost to the economy now would pay off in the longer term because activity would strengthen, tax revenues would rise and the deficit would therefore come down more quickly.

In reality, Osborne's policy is now an uneasy compromise between these two competing ideas. The chancellor believes that a "credible" deficit reduction plan is vital to keep interest rates low, but at the same time is wary of intensifying the austerity in case it pushes the economy into a double dip recession.

Osborne is now in the position of having to react to every concern raised by the rating agencies about the adverse interplay between growth and the deficit with an inflexible insistence that policy will not be changed under any circumstances. This is not a good place to be; it runs the risk of further depressing the economy and illustrates starkly the risk of paying too much attention to the ratings agencies.

webTitle: Ireland oil strike raises hopes for exploration boom

fields.bodyText: Oil has been struck off the County Cork coast in a potentially multibillion-pound discovery that could help to drag Ireland's recession-stricken economy out of the mire. Dublin-based Providence Resources announced on Thursday that oil has successfully started to flow from its Barryroe well in the first big find in Irish territorial waters. The oilfield, which is about 50 kilometres off the Cork coast, has a flow of more than 3,500 barrels a day, a number which exceeds the company's original projections of 1,800 barrels. One recent audit of the area found that it might contain the potential to produce almost 1bn barrels of oil, making the field worth billions at today's crude prices of well over $100 a barrel. The test area off the Cork coast covered 300 sq km, which according to Providence is equivalent to a medium-to-large North Sea oil field. The oil was discovered at a depth of about 100 metres in the sea bed. Successful drilling at the Barryroe well will increase pressure on the Irish government to grant permission for oil exploration at five further sites in Irish waters. These include the most controversial site, at Dalkey Island in Dublin Bay, close to an exclusive stretch of the capital's coastline which is home to Irish rock stars such as Bono and Enya. If an oil rig were constructed near the uninhabited island it would be in the line of sight of homes belonging to celebrities on Dublin's so-called "gold coast". An alliance of community groups in one of the richest parts of Ireland as well as conservation groups such as Birdwatch Ireland and An Taisce, the republic's National Trust, are understood to be planning a campaign against the drilling project. The island is home to a seal colony and the waters around it are used for fishing pollock and mackerel as well sea diving. Providence Resources, whose chief executive is Tony O'Reilly Jr, the son of the former boss of Independent News and Media, said it was pleased the flow rates from Barryroe were higher than the pre-drilling target. O'Reilly said the discovery was a "seminal day for Ireland, especially in the runup to St Patrick's Day". Of the higher than expected oil flows he said: "As the Americans say, 'We didn't hit a home run, we knocked the ball out of the park'. I think this discovery also creates a reappraisal in the minds of global oil corporations about coming back to Irish waters to drill for oil. Irish territorial waters are massively under-explored." The oil was of good quality, described as "light but waxy crude". O'Reilly said the company was exploring for oil in Northern Ireland near Rathlin Island and he hoped the Barryroe find would lead to the creation of an onshore oil industry in Ireland. "We've always said as an Irish company we want to use as much Irish infrastructure and resources as we can. We don't have an oil industry in Ireland at present but I hope something like Barryroe and the success we are getting in that will thrive more interest in creating more of an infrastructure in Ireland." While the find is small by the standards of the Middle East or even the North Sea it could reduce the republic's national energy bill and have a significant spinoff for the entire economy. Ireland is heavily dependent on imported oil and gas. The Irish Offshore Operators' Association points out that more than 90% of Irish gas is imported while oil accounts for nearly 60% of overall Irish energy consumption. Fergus Cahill of the Irish Offshore Operators' Association said: "It's very encouraging and positive. First of all it's the first discovery in Irish waters that looks to be declared commercial. The flow rates are encouraging. Secondly, it will encourage other explorers because one of the problems that have dogged Ireland has been the explorations in the past. Almost all of these discoveries were of gas, not oil. If it gets developed, which we hope it will, it will reduce our dependency on imports, increase taxation revenue and create jobs." The Irish exchequer will benefit from the potential oil boom as the republic's department of finance gains a 25% tax take from any oil or gas revenues.

webTitle: Shell boss got £10m pay package amid oil price surge

fields.standfirst: Energy firm reveals that chief executive's pay doubled in 2011 as it admits to 207 oil spills, up from 195 the previous year
fields.body:
Shell chief executive Peter Voser earned more than £10m last year in pay and bonuses at a time of near-record oil prices and in a year when the firm was responsible for 207 oil spills – considerably more than the year before.

The remuneration, made up of salary, bonuses and long-term incentive schemes, was more than double the figure for 2010 but the company said it was justified by Shell's strong operating and share-price performance. The oil firm reported global annual earnings of $28.6bn (£18bn) in 2011 – or more than £2m an hour – a 54% increase on the previous year.

The Anglo-Dutch group has cashed in on surging oil prices – which were more than $30 a barrel higher in 2011 than in 2010 – and booming demand for gas. It makes most of its money outside Britain and claims to generate barely 1p a litre profit from petrol sales.

Voser's £10.4m payout is composed of £4.52m in annual salary and bonus, with the balance from long-term incentive schemes. A spokeswoman said the payout "is a jump, but it's a reflection of a number of different factors and includes a payout from a share scheme that has been running for three years".

But she said the remuneration policy had not changed and she could not rule out another bumper payout next year.

Voser's pay was revealed in the company's annual report less than 24 hours after directors were criticised by British MPs for alleged complacency over safety plans for future drilling in the Arctic.

Shell said in its report that the number of "operational spills over 100 kilograms" increased to 207 during 2011 from 195 in 2010, but it admitted the figure for last year could still grow. The group is still investigating a further four spills in Nigeria that it admits "may result in adjustments to the 2011 data". A similar adjustment was made to the 2010 number.

Among the confirmed spills last year was a leak from a pipeline connected to the Gannet Alpha platform in the North Sea, plus one off the Bonga field in Nigeria. The company said that it regretted both incidents, but had taken "prompt and comprehensive response actions".

Shell is particularly vulnerable to spills in Nigeria, some of which have been caused by sabotage. Its activities were heavily criticised by a UN environment programme report last year.

The company is trying to reduce the amount of gas flared off in Nigeria into the atmosphere. But the annual report also said flaring, a major cause of greenhouse gases, would increase next year in Iraq.

Shell admitted that environmental problems it was still grappling with included 23 square kilometres of "ponds" containing toxic metals caused by the mining of tar sands at Athabasca in Alberta, Canada. It said it was still working with local authorities on what to do about the discovery of fresh water from a local aquifer in the bottom of one pond at the Muskeg River Mine, Athabasca.

Shell also admitted it has been – along with other energy companies – facing legal challenges over responsibility for carbon emissions and therefore climate change. It said in the report that the claims were "without merit".

The report also showed that Malcolm Brinded, who competed against Voser for the top job and missed out, would leave the company with a ¤2.5m (£2.1m) payoff "in line with the policy introduced in 2010". He will also get a "pro-rated" performance bonus and the company will make good on any financial loss made on a house bought in Holland when he moved there in 2002.

fields.headline: Shell boss got £10m pay package amid oil price surge
fields.trailText: Energy firm reveals that chief executive's pay doubled in 2011 as it admits to 207 oil spills, up from 195 the previous year

webTitle: Eurozone crisis at heart of UK's economic woes, MPC member says

fields.standfirst: Bank of England's Ben Broadbent warns interest rates could climb as soon as eurozone crisis is resolved
fields.body:
The eurozone crisis and the sucker punch it delivered to the UK banking sector is at the heart of the UK's current economic woes, a Bank of England policymaker said on Thursday, giving support to the chancellor's view that external forces are largely to blame for the country's current predicament.

Ben Broadbent, a Goldman Sachs economist who joined the central bank's monetary policy committee last year, also warned that interest rates could start to climb as soon as the eurozone crisis is resolved.

In a speech to City executives, he said an analysis of the last decade showed that dealing with the massive debts racked up by UK banks ahead of the Lehman Brothers collapse is more significant to exiting the recession than driving down household debts.

Banks faced a double whammy from the euro crisis, which triggered a second credit crunch and restricted their ability to restructure an exposure to loans across the world.

"What distinguished the UK, more than the indebtedness of its non-financial private sector, was the size of its banks' overseas balance sheets," he said.

"To the extent that any single thing can be a useful diagnostic on the state of credit markets, and the prospects for sustainable recovery, it is therefore more likely to be found directly in the UK banking system (its funding costs, for example) than in the domestic non-financial sector.

"And though the latter can affect the former, it remains the case that the most important risks facing the UK banks, and therefore the supply of domestic credit, emanate from outside the UK."

Households spent much of the 1990s and 2000s building up debts, mainly through an escalation of mortgage loans.

But older households who sold at the top of the market largely invested their gains in other savings products and pensions, leaving the net position of the household sector roughly the same as in 1990, said Broadbent. He said this development had huge implications for the intergenerational transfer of wealth from young people forced to take on larger mortgages and older people who sold their homes, but meant the rise in bank debts was related to commercial and international loans.

He said: "At the end of the 1990s, UK-owned banks had estimated overseas exposures of £500bn or so. By mid-2008 these had grown to over £2,500bn. This is significantly more than their exposure to the domestic economy, around twice (specifically) their lending to the UK non-financial private sector.

"In terms of changes, these estimates imply that overseas assets contributed almost six times more to the growth of UK-owned banks' aggregate balance sheets than did loans to domestic households and non-financial firms."

He argues that it is these overseas assets that pose the biggest risk to banks and when the global economy returns to health, so will bank balance sheets. When that happens, the Bank of England's MPC will start to raise rates.

"If we focus solely on domestic debts (residential mortgages in particular) we are in danger of being too parochial about the key risks facing the economy," he said. "What distinguished the UK was not so much the size of its mortgage market but the extent and riskiness of its banks' overseas balance sheets.

"It is there that most of the losses were made, and there still, in my view, that the larger risks reside. As such, it is perfectly possible that funding and credit conditions could improve, and a withdrawal of monetary accommodation become warranted, quite independently of the gearing of domestic creditors."

webTitle: Essar Energy moves higher after refinery news, but FTSE 100 slips back

fields.standfirst: Indian power group set to lose FTSE 100 place but gives positive update on refinery commissioning
fields.body:
Essar Energy may be about to be kicked out of the FTSE 100 at the close of play on Friday following the latest quarterly reshuffle, but its shares are leading the index at the moment.

They have climbed 2.6p to 115p after it completed another stage in the expansion of its Vadinar refinery in India. It has commissioned a diesel hydrotreater unit, leaving three more units to be brought on stream by the end of the month.

Overall the FTSE 100 is drifting lower, off 12.04 points at 5933.39, with relative calm in the eurozone crisis and relatively positive news from the US economy. Fitch's threatened downgrade to the UK's Triple A credit rating was hardly unexpected and has caused few ructions.

Next has climbed 64p to £28.91 after better than expected figures from rival H&M and a buy note from Panmure Gordon ahead of next Thursday's full year figures. The broker said:

The company has already guided a 2012 pretax profit of "£7m either side of £565m". Our estimate is £572.6m, at the top of this guided range. The focus next Thursday will be on any new guidance for 2013. The January statement guided the market to 2013 profits "only slightly up" on 2012. Our estimate of £593.1m implies 3.6% growth, around 1% ahead of consensus on £586.6m. With stable year on year selling prices and a very favourable input pricing environment, we think that 2013 guidance is probably too conservative.

And more from Shire. Its shares are now the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 after it withdrew its US licence application for its Fabry disease treatment. It has also announced the purchase of US biotech firm FerroKin BioSciences for up to $325m.

Among the mid-caps, Domino Printing Sciences is down 86.5p at 577p after it said it was unlikely to see any sales growth this year because of difficult markets in Europe and fewer large orders from China. Seymour Pierce cut its recommendation from buy to hold but said:

We see no reason to panic though. Noting that we saw a similar wobble in forecasts in 2009 only for the end result to be little different to initial expectations we take our share price target back to 600p, equivalent to a 2012 PE of 17 times.

White van specialist Northgate has fallen 15.1p to 223.1p after warning 2012 profits would be at the lower end of expectations, due to weak rental demand in the UK and Spain, and the company was also taking a cautious view of 2013.

IT group Misys is down 4.3p at 320.7p after Swiss rival Temenos - which withdrew its merger proposal earlier this week - issued a downbeat trading update. Misys is still in the sights of two potential bidders, Vista Equity Partners and a joint bid from CVC Capital and ValueAct. Analysts at Espirito Santo said:

Following the termination of the merger discussions, Temenos last night held a conference call to provide guidance for 2012. At the mid-point the revenue and adjusted earnings guidance was 2% lower than that of consensus. The company re-iterated its view that market conditions remain difficult and sales cycles are much longer compared to 2008-09. This is in line with our view that the market conditions in the banking software market are worse than what we saw in 2008-09.
This clearly has negative implications for the potential price that [private equity companies] would be willing to pay. On a separate note, Temenos management also noted that it saw little impact on its pipeline due to the merger discussions with Misys. In our view, this could be because customers were certain that even if the two companies merged, Temenos' core-banking product will the solution of choice. However, negative for Misys as there is likely to have been customer uncertainty negatively affecting the adoption of BankFusion; next event – Vista bid deadline is Monday.

webTitle: US weekly jobless figures and New York manufacturing index both beat forecasts

fields.standfirst: New claims for benefits fell last week while Empire index rose in March
fields.body:
A raft of US data has just been released and it seems reasonably positive on the whole, with weekly jobless numbers and New York manufacturing both beating expectations.

New claims for unemployment benefit fell to 351,000 last week, compared to expectations of around 356,000 and the previous week's 365,000 (which was in turn revised upwards from 362,000.) The four week moving average was steady at 355,750.

The Empire general business conditions index rose to 20.21 in March, up from 19.53 in February and better than forecasts of a decline to 17.5. But new orders slipped from 9.73 to 6.84 and prices paid jumped to their highest level since June 2011.

webTitle: HMV confirms buyers interested in live music business

fields.standfirst: Struggling music retailer hopes to sell operator of Hammersmith Apollo and Kentish Town Forum to pay off some of its debts
fields.body:
HMV, the struggling DVD and music retailer, has confirmed it has received approaches from several potential buyers for HMV Live, the music venue business it acquired two years ago.

US billionaire Philip Anschutz, whose AEG empire includes the O2 Area in the Docklands area of London, is reported to be among those interested. Also said to be circling are Academy Music Group, which runs the Brixton Academy and Shepherd's Bush Empire, and Peter Dubens's Oakley Capital, which last year took a controlling interest in Time Out.

HMV Live is the UK's second largest multiple venue operator with 13 sites including the Hammersmith Apollo, the Forum in Kentish Town and Camden's Jazz Cafe. It is also a leading operator of music festivals. The business is expected to fetch a price of about £60m which would help pay down HMV's high borrowings.

In January HMV won critical support from film house and record label suppliers which enabled chief executive Simon Fox to secure essential concessions from the group's lending banks led by taxpayer-controlled Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group.

HMV has closed stores and sold off its Waterstones business in an effort to pay down debts to more manageable levels, but borrowings remain uncomfortably high.

In January Fox said he believed net debt would reach somewhere between £175m and £180m by the end of April, but – based on prevailing trading patterns – can be halved within three years.

Having acquired Aim-listed MAMA in 2010 for £47m, HMV told investors that its total investment in the Live music division was £62.5m. Investors were told the new live music division was expected to generate operating profits of about £15m in 2012/12.

In a statement on Thursday morning, HMV said: "HMV Group notes the recent press speculation regarding the strategic review of the HMV Live business. HMV can confirm that this review remains on-going and that a number of parties have indicated an interest in acquiring the business."

webTitle: Shire withdraws US licence application for its Fabry disease treatment

fields.standfirst: Company says it expected quick approval but US regulators wanted additional controlled trials
fields.body:
Shire has withdrawn its US licence application for its treatment for Fabry disease, a rare genetic disorder, after signs regulators wanted more tests on the drug.

The company had been supplying the drug Replagal in the US for around two years - it has been on the market in Europe since 2001 - following manufacturing problems with rival treatment Fabrzyme, made by Genzyme.

Shire said it filed a licence application in November last year "in anticipation of a quick review process and eventual approval." But it said recent discussions with the US Food and Drug Administration led it to believe the regulator wanted additional controlled trials before giving any approval:

No concerns over the product's safety profile were raised by the FDA. Shire has concluded the likely additional studies would cause a significant delay and an approval of Replagal for UK patients would only be possible in the distant future.

Shire executive Sylvie Gregoire added:

Shire has a close partnership with the global Fabry patient community for over ten years, and we are extremely disappointed that we feel compelled to make this decision.

The FDA said Shire had also decided to end its treatment programme over the next few months, so the drug would no longer be available to US patients. It said it was disappointed by Shire's decision and would work with Shire or other companies to develop new treatments for Fabry disease.

The news has helped send Shire's shares - recently boosted by bid speculation - 22p lower to £22.06 and analyst Emmanuel Papadakis at Collins Stewart issued a sell note:

The news that Replagal is unlikely to be approved in the US is surprising and means a modest treatment pool (140 US patients, around 20% of the current US treated patient pool) is now not likely to be converted into a commercial revenue stream.
Shire has been treating US patients free of charge on an effective emergency access basis since Genzyme (now Sanofi) encountered severe and protracted manufacturing difficulties with the only competitor (Fabrazyme) several years ago. Without access to the US patient pool our peak $670m sales for Replagal are still achievable but ambitious, whilst consensus numbers (around 10% ahead our ours) will clearly need a small trim.

webTitle: Home Retail calls for budget help for consumers as sales fall again at Argos and Homebase

fields.standfirst: Retail group backs call for tax threshold to be raised as Argos like-for-likes drop 8.5%
fields.body:
Home Retail, the owner of Argos and Homebase, has urged the government to give some help in next week's budget to low and middle income consumers - its core customers.

It agrees with proposals to raise the threshold at which people begin paying tax, the company said after reporting another set of falling sales in the fourth - eight week - quarter.

Argos like-for-like sales dropped 8.5% while Homebase fell 6.5%. The company said it was still on course to meet full year profit expectations (of around £99m), and its shares - lifted on Wednesday by a positive note from JP Morgan Cazenove - have edged up 1p to 116p.

But Philip Dorgan at Panmure Gordon repeated his sell advice, and his call for Argos to close some of its stores:

The period reported has been short and is low volume. The figures are poor, but not unexpected. Argos may benefit from the demise of Game, but there are plenty of other retailers competing for the same business.

We note that the new managing director of Argos [John Walden] held a series of interviews with the press last month, in which he said that he had been given a blank piece of paper. We think that he needs to start writing a list of store closures on it. While it may be true that Argos has few stores that don't make a contribution to overhead, this does not mean that this will perpetuate in an online world, with both Tesco and Amazon continuing to invest substantially.

We remain sellers with a target price of 60p.

David Jeary at Investec also has a sell recommendation:

The good news from the fourth quarter update is that there is no change to the 2012 pretax profit outlook, and that the year-end net cash position will be around £40m better than previously flagged.

The less good news is that Argos has seen no improvement in its like-for-like run rate, and that the debate around cyclical pressures versus structural decline is set to continue. The next sentiment driver in our view will come when the market hears the plans of newly appointed Argos managing director, possibly at the May preliminary results.

webTitle: Oil find off Ireland by Dublin's Providence Resources boosts hopes for country's economy

fields.standfirst: Explorer run by Tony O'Reilly junior optimistic after drilling update from south Ireland field
fields.body:
Ireland, which needed a €85bn bailout in 2010 and whose economy is still struggling amid the eurozone crisis, received a boost with news is could become an oil producer.

Dublin-based explorer Providence Resources - whose chief executive is Tony O'Reilly junior, son of the former rugby player and media magnate - has just issued a positive drilling update for its Barryroe well off the south of the country. It has found very high quality oil, with flow rates that could make the field a commercial prospect. It flowed oil at a rate of 3,514 barrels a day, above the company's target of 1,800. Further testing will take place before the well is suspended to explore the potential for further drilling.

Any production could prove a boon to the beleaguered Irish economy. O'Reilly told Reuters:

The successful exploitation of hydrocarbons could be very rewarding because anywhere from 25% to 40% tax would be payable on a commercial development, that would be a very big boom for the Irish exchequer.

Providence, where the O'Reilly family has a 20% stake, jumped 55.5p to 485.5p on the news, valuing the company at nearly £250m. Its partner in the field is Landsdowne Oil & Gas, up 5.5p at 60.25, while Royal Dutch Shell also has operations in Ireland, as does Petrel Resources, up 1p at 8.375p. Analysts at Liberum Capital said:

Providence has reported flow rates from Barryroe that should confirm the commerciality of the field. Other data indicate that estimates of both oil-in-place and recovery factors will be raised holding out the prospect of material increases in valuation. There could be significant upside to our 880p price target from Barryroe upgrades and recognition of value elsewhere in the portfolio.

Fox Davis Research was also positive, saying:

The company and its partners believe that the results have so far exceeded their expectations - site survey, 3D acquisition/processing, rig procurement, drilling & testing, etc. The characteristics of the oil alone coupled with the potential sidetrack drilling should excite and thus move the needle for investors.

webTitle: Tesco UK chief quits: analyst reaction

fields.standfirst: The shock departure of Richard Brasher, head of Tesco in the UK, has left City analysts predicting generational change at the top of Britain's biggest retailer
fields.body:
Andrew Kasoulis at Credit Suisse

The move is not a complete surprise as the press has been reporting tensions between Brasher/Clarke for some time – the FT, for example, had been suggesting that Brasher had wanted to push deeper with price cuts and the two disagreed on strategy. We think it is probably simpler than that – Clarke wanting very close day-to-day control of the UK and Brasher maybe not happy/prepared for two captains to run the same ship.

Also, Clarke has recently moved key trusted executives from his prior international role into UK jobs – Chris Bush (ex-Thailand) now heads UK retail and Ken Towle (ex-China) heads UK online – so he has very much moulded the UK team … Given better sales recently (as reported by Kantar/Nielsen), we think Brasher's departure is more a result of the two personalities than as a result of deteriorating numbers.

Shore Capital

Tesco's misjudgments have been clearly spoken about by Philip Clarke, with comments that relate to an over-focus on store costs and stock management over customer service amongst other things. Accordingly, a central, indeed the central component of the announcement from the company on 12 January that amounted to a profit warning for the 2012-13 financial year, was the need to reinvest in labour and proposition to improvement competitiveness of the core chain at a cost to UK margins.

The departure of Mr Brasher, who it must be said has had a glowing career at Tesco, follows that of David Potts and Andrew Higginson from the Tesco main board in recent times, reflecting the generational adjustment taking place following the surprise retirement of Sir Terry Leahy, announced in March 2010. That change of generation in any company brings with it the dangers of inertia and disruptive adjustment that is naturally to be expected to some extent until the 'new' settles in.

At the same time and reflecting the changing shape of the business, Mr Clarke is building a new group-wide management structure that probably reflects more effectively the nature and extent of Tesco today and where it wants to go as the world's third largest retailer. Quite how that new management structure works and performs is yet to be measured, but we certainly cannot fault Mr Clarke for demonstrating decisiveness and energy.

Analysts at JP Morgan Cazenove

The UK remains Tesco's biggest challenge and Mr Clarke's more direct involvement should reassure shareholders that his focus remains on this key challenge. Given Mr Clarke's direct involvement, Mr Brasher's role in the business became less clear and as a consequence he has taken the decision to leave the business in July. The change should herald a new wave of generational managers with the very well regarded Mr Bush, recently appointed COO of UK stores, now in pole position for further ascension. We do not consider this likely to be a permanent arrangement given the obvious concerns of Mr Clarke becoming too stretched but with the US now showing progress and the bank seemingly progressing towards the launch of new products, Mr Clarke has more time to address the UK's problems right now.

Panmure

Having a group CEO and a CEO of the UK is all very well when things are going swimmingly. However, with the UK, 70% of the business and underperforming, it becomes difficult to have two captains on the bridge. Therefore, the departure of Richard Brasher is a sad, but perhaps inevitable, consequence of the recent profit warning … That is the official version and we believe it, for once.

webTitle: Tesco UK boss quits supermarket in aftermath of shock profit warning

fields.standfirst: 'You can't have two captains' declares Philip Clarke as he takes direct control of UK operations at Britain's largest retailer
fields.body:
Tesco chief executive Philip Clarke declared "you can't have two captains" as he took direct control of the supermarket group's UK operations on Thursday morning.

Richard Brasher, head of Tesco in the UK, has quit the board with immediate effect. The 50-year-old will leave Britain's largest retailer, where he has worked for 26 years, in July.

His departure follows reports of tensions between Brasher and the chief executive. Clarke was forced to issue a shock profit warning in January which wiped £5bn off the value of the company.

Clarke last week dismissed suggestions of a rift, but on Thursday morning was more outspoken: "You can't have two captains in a team," he told Reuters.

He also stressed the abrupt exit of Brasher did "not signal another [profit] warning". Market research data suggests Tesco has been making some progress to recover lost ground in the UK in the last two months. In January the supermarket's UK market share slipped below 30% for the first time since 2005.

In a statement to the stock exchange, Clarke said he would personally take over responsibility for UK operations "at this very important time".

He added: "This greater focus will allow me to oversee the improvements that are so important for customers. I completely understand why Richard has decided to leave and want to thank him for the great contribution he has made over many years.

"He will leave behind a UK business which has very strong plans for improvement, and over the last two months these plans are beginning to show progress, in line with our expectations. I am more determined than ever that these improvements in the UK will result in a better Tesco and an even better shopping trip for customers."

Brasher had only been in charge of the UK and Irish business since March last year and has sat on the board for eight years, previously holding a series of senior executive posts in marketing, commercial and store operations.

His departure marks another step in the stealthy reshuffle of senior UK executives in the wake of last Christmas's disappointing results.

Marketing director Carolyn Bradley left the UK board to take up the new role of group brand director. Bob Robbins, who effectively served as deputy to Brasher, also left the board for a newly created role at group level. Tesco insisted the shifts did not amount to demotions.

Bradley is replaced by David Wood, the commercial director in Hungary who has previous marketing experience with Unilever and Kraft. Meanwhile, Robbins is replaced by seasoned Tesco executive Chris Bush, who is returning from a role running operations in Thailand.
